title: Crossing epigenetic frontiers: the intersection of novel histone modifications and diseases
affiliations: Department of Hematology, Shandong Provincial Hospital Affiliated to Shandong First Medical University, Jinan, Shandong 250021, China

background: Histone post-translational modifications (HPTMs) are crucial for epigenetic regulation and are increasingly implicated in various diseases.
hypotheses: Do novel histone modifications play significant roles in disease development and progression?
Can novel HPTM inhibitors be developed as effective therapeutic agents?
What are the underlying molecular mechanisms of novel HPTMs in various diseases?
major_findings: Nine novel histone modifications (lactylation, citrullination, crotonylation, succinylation, SUMOylation, propionylation, butyrylation, 2-hydroxyisobutyrylation, and 2-hydroxybutyrylation) were comprehensively reviewed.
These novel HPTMs are involved in various cellular processes, including transcription, replication, DNA repair, and metabolism.
Novel HPTMs are implicated in the development and progression of various diseases, including cancers, cardiovascular diseases, infectious diseases, and neuropsychiatric disorders.
Emerging strategies for targeting novel HPTMs as therapeutic targets and biomarkers were discussed.
Novel epigenetic research techniques and their applications in the field of novel HPTM research were briefly introduced.
new_open_questions: What are the precise biological functions and regulatory mechanisms of novel HPTMs?
Can highly efficient and selective inhibitors of novel HPTMs be developed?
What are the interplay and competitive mechanisms between novel HPTMs and other epigenetic modifications?
What are the roles of novel HPTMs in other diseases beyond those discussed in this review?
